Application of Y-27632 alone changed the polarity of neurites and promoted their elongation (Fig. 5 A) as reported previously (13Bito H. Furuyashiki T. Ishihara H. Shibasaki Y. Ohashi K. Mizuno K. Maekawa M. Ishizaki T. Narumiya S. Neuron. 2000; 26: 431-441Google Scholar, 14Yamasaki T. Kawaji K. Ono K. Bito H. Hirano T. Osumi M. Kengaku M. Development (Camb.). 2001; 128: 3133-3144Google Scholar). mDia effects on multibranching or neurite length became more prominent in the presence of this drug in some neurites (Fig. 5, B and C). Neurite shortening was evoked by expression of RhoV14 or ROCKΔ3 as reported previously (Fig. 5, D and F), and the shortening was reversed by co-expression of mDia (Fig. 5, E andG). In Fig. 5 G, the existence of mDia at the growth cone was observed (white circle). Furthremore, lamellipodia-like neurites were observed in some cells (Figs. 4 C and 5 E). These data suggest that the mDia effects on neurite extension and multibranching are different from those of the Rho/ROCK pathway, which causes growth cone contraction and neurite retraction via myosin light chain phosphorylation (11Kaibuchi K. Kuroda S. Amano M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1999; 68: 459-486Google Scholar, 25Amano M. Chihara K. Nakamura N. Fukata Y. Yano T. Shibata M. Ikebe M. Kaibuchi K. Genes Cells. 1998; 3: 177-188Google Scholar).DISCUSSIONmDia, a formin homology protein and a target protein of the small GTPase, Rho, is known to be involved in cytoskeletal reorganization (stress fiber formation and microtubule organization (26Ishizaki T. Morishima Y. Okamoto M. Furuyashiki T. Kato T. Narumiya S. Nat. Cell Biol. 2001; 3: 8-14Google Scholar)) and cytokinesis. The mechanistic basis for the effect of mDia on stress fiber formation is thought to include the de novo production of actin filaments (1Watanabe N. Madaule P. Reid T. Ishizaki T. Watanabe G. Kakizuka A. Saito Y. Nakao K. Jockusch B.M. Narumiya S. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3044-3056Google Scholar, 5Satoh S. Tominaga T. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 39290-39294Google Scholar). This stress fiber formation occurs in cooperation with ROCK, which causes F-actin contraction through myosin light chain phosphorylation (25Amano M. Chihara K. Nakamura N. Fukata Y. Yano T. Shibata M. Ikebe M. Kaibuchi K. Genes Cells. 1998; 3: 177-188Google Scholar). It has also been reported that mDia regulates the transcription of focal adhesion molecules through the activation of serum response factor (4Tominaga T. Sahai E. Chardin P. McCormick F. Courtneidge S.A. Alberts A.S. Mol. Cell. 2000; 5: 13-25Google Scholar, 27Sotiropoulos A. Gineitis D. Copeland J. Treisman R. Cell. 1999; 98: 159-169Google Scholar). Mutations of formin homology proteins in all species examined are known to cause defects in cytokinesis (1Watanabe N. Madaule P. Reid T. Ishizaki T. Watanabe G. Kakizuka A. Saito Y. Nakao K. In the present study, we showed that mDia caused neurite extension and multibranching in cerebellar granule neurons in the pathway distinct from that of Rho/ROCK. This represents the first description of positive effects of mDia on neurite extension and multibranching and suggests that mDia and ROCK might regulate the axon outgrowth in balance in the downstream of Rho activation.The data presented here clearly demonstrate that mDia can localize to the nucleus, bind directly to Pax6, and alter the expression level and localization pattern of Pax6 in heterologous expression systems. Moreover, some of these mDia effects were also observed in native neurons. Parsons J.T. Science. 1999; 286: 1102-1103Google Scholar). These facts, together with our studies, suggest that mDia, too, might play a role in neurite outgrowth and cell migration by inhibiting the Pax6-dependent transcriptional regulation of molecules such as F-actin, microtuble, cadherin, and other guidance cues. The neurite multibranching and lamellipodia-like neurites observed in cerebellar granule cells of Sey rat (14Yamasaki T. Kawaji K. Ono K. Bito H. Hirano T. Osumi M. Kengaku M. Development (Camb.). 2001; 128: 3133-3144Google Scholar) and mDia-induced neurite changes might share similar origins. Rho GTPases (Rac and Cdc42) have been shown to be involved in neuronal growth cone morphology, neurite extension, and axonal pathfinding during early central nervous system development (33Luo L. Nat. Rev. Neurosci. 2000; 1: 173-180Google Scholar, 34Dickson B.J. Opin. Neurobiol. 2001; 11: 103-110Google Scholar). On the other hand, Rho kinase causes neurite contraction. This apparent importance of Rho GTPases to the morphology of neurites is consistent with the proposed effects of mDia, which might act to some extent through its interaction with Pax6. However, our data did not exclude the possibility that mDia alone can cause neurite extension and morphological changes. Examining the effects of mDia on the neurons lacking Pax6 expression could provide more information about the role of mDia and its interaction with Rho GTPases. mDia (a mammalian homologue of Drosophila diaphanous) is a target of the small GTPase, Rho (1Watanabe N. We therefore examined whether mDia could enter the nucleus by using leptomycin B (24Kudo N. Matsumori N. Taoka H. Fujiwara D. Schreiner E.R. Wolff B. Yoshida M. Horinouchi S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 9112-9117Google Scholar), an inhibitor of nuclear pore component, exportin. As shown in Fig.1 A, treatment of transfected NIH3T3 cells with leptomycin B caused GFP-mDia2 to change its localization from a diffuse pattern to an exclusively nuclear pattern. We also observed that while Pax6 was located exclusively in the nucleus when expressed in HeLa or NIH3T3 cells, co-expression of mDia and Pax6 resulted in a mixed, nuclear and cytosolic Pax6 immunostaining pattern (Fig. 1 B). Such a cytosolic Pax6 immunostaining was never observed in cells expressing Pax6 with mDia lacking an N terminus (data not shown). These findings prompted us to examine the in vivo interaction of mDia and Pax6 using a Dual-Luciferase Assay System (Fig. 1 C). Injection of d-tubocurarine chloride into certain insects produces complete flaccid paralysis. The site of injection is closely related to the region of primary paralysis. The effect depends on concentration, with distinct differences in the optimum concentrations for various species so far tested. A dose-response curve has been prepared for Calliphora erythrocephala.

The α<sub>M</sub>β<sub>2</sub>integrin plays an important role in leukocyte biology through its interactions with a diverse set of ligands. Efficient ligand binding requires the involvement of both the α<sub>M</sub> and β<sub>2</sub> subunits. Past ligand binding studies have focused mainly on the α<sub>M</sub> subunit, with the β<sub>2</sub>subunit being largely unexplored. Therefore, in this study we conducted homolog-scanning mutagenesis on the I-domain (residues 125–385) within the β<sub>2</sub> subunit. We identified four noncontiguous sequences (Arg<sup>144</sup>–Lys<sup>148</sup>, Gln<sup>199</sup>–Ala<sup>203</sup>, Leu<sup>225</sup>–Leu<sup>230</sup>, and Gly<sup>305</sup>–His<sup>309</sup>) that are critical for fibrinogen and C3bi binding to α<sub>M</sub>β<sub>2</sub>. Molecular modeling revealed that these four sequences reside within a narrow region on the surface of the β<sub>2</sub>I-domain, in close proximity to three potential cation-binding sites. Among these sequences, Gln<sup>199</sup>–Ala<sup>203</sup>, Leu<sup>225</sup>–Leu<sup>230</sup>, and Gly<sup>305</sup>–His<sup>309</sup> are important for the binding of both ligands, whereas Arg<sup>144</sup>–Lys<sup>148</sup> is more critical for fibrinogen than for C3bi binding. These sequences within the β<sub>2</sub>I-domain are directly involved in ligand binding, since 1) switching these segments to their corresponding β<sub>1</sub> sequences destroyed ligand binding; 2) loss of function was not due to a nonspecific gross conformational change, since the defective α<sub>M</sub>β<sub>2</sub> mutants reacted well with a panel of conformation-dependent mAbs; 3) mutation of these functional sequences did not effect Ca<sup>2+</sup>binding; and 4) synthetic peptides corresponding to sequences Gln<sup>199</sup>–Ala<sup>203</sup> and Gly<sup>305</sup>–His<sup>309</sup> blocked ligand binding to α<sub>M</sub>β<sub>2</sub>, and the peptides interacted directly with fibrinogen and C3bi. Given the similarity among all integrin β subunits, our results may help us to understand the underlying mechanism of integrin-ligand interactions in general.

Prophylactic protection against cyanide intoxication in mice can be enhanced by the administration of oxygen, especially when it is used in combination with the conventional cyanide antidotes, sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate. The LD(50) values were compared in groups of mice premedicated with sodium thiosulfate or sodium nitrite, or both, in air and in oxygen. These results indicate that oxygen alone provides only minimal protection. Although oxygen enhances the protective effect of sodium thiosulfate to a minor degree, it does not enhance the protection of sodium nitrite at all; and yet, it potentiates the effectiveness of a combination of these two antagonists against cyanide intoxication.

In postnatal rabbits there is progressive development of central regulation of the micturition reflex. During the first 1 to 2 days of postnatal life a coordinated sustained reflex may be obtained from the bladder which has been isolated from the central nervous system. Changes in reflex integration occur over the following 7 to 12 days, which result in a coordinated reflex dependent upon supraspinal influiences.
